awd_titl_txt: RUI: Interactions between language and cognition in the early acquisition of spatial language
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide a better understanding of how preverbal infants represent spatial configurations, and of how linguistic input and experiences with objects in the first four years of life affect early spatial representations. Specifically, in studies of children acquiring spatial language, the project will explore interactions between their understanding of spatial configurations, the language they hear, and their experience with objects. The research will provide detailed understanding of early spatial term development, thus illuminating how these terms might enable the expression of abstract spatial relationships pertinent to STEM-related disciplines. The research also has the potential to contribute to understanding of spatial and language deficits in individuals with developmental disorders (such as autism or William syndrome). Finally, this project will give a diverse set of students from underrepresented groups experience with all aspects of a scientific research project. Mentoring will be conducted by two faculty in different laboratories and Universities, thus offering students exposure to scientific research and instilling in them an appreciation for scientific discovery. 

This project is highly inter-disciplinary. It uses an approach that is motivated by linguistic analyses of spatial terms, it proposes clear hypotheses built on findings from studies of infant cognition and language development, and it utilizes state-of-the art research methods for studying infant cognition and language development. The project will study spatial language development by examining three components likely to play a significant role in spatial language acquisition: (a) core spatial concepts, (b) linguistic input, and (c) specific experiences with objects. To systematically test the interaction of these components, the project will focus on the domain of "support." The core concept of "support from below" will be tested in children 6 months to 4.5 years of age, using infant looking time paradigms and early language comprehension paradigms, as well as spontaneous and elicited language production methods. The influence of linguistic input on children's understanding of support will be tested by relating parents' language of support to children's language development, and by relating specific support language, such as "is on" or "sticks to," to children's spatial representations. The influence of children's experience with objects on their understanding of support will be tested by examining how their experiences with object properties relevant for support, such as "stickiness," influence early support understanding.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored language development in children 6-months to 4.5 years of age. The focus was on how spatial meanings (e.g., on) in language are formed in young children, based on the joint roles of (a) a hypothesized core spatial concept and (b) linguistic input from parents. Our research has shown that support from below may indeed be a core concept for the domain of support which is then privileged in the mapping to spatial language. By twenty-months of age, children prefer to map "on" and "BE on" to support from below (e.g., the toy is on top of the box) over other support configurations, such as support via mechanical forces such as adhesion (the toy is on the side of the box). Further, by 36 months, children map lexical verbs (e.g., stick, hang, in English) to mechanical support, which may be influenced by parent input. Parents of children 6- to 42-months, used distinct language to encode SFB and mechanical support to their children ("she put the toy on the box" for SFB vs. "she stuck the toy on the box" for mechanical support), with parents of the oldest children (31-42 months) using more specific lexical verbs of support ("stick"). Thus, parents' use of lexical verbs (e.g., "stick") may play a major role in children acquiring the spatial language to encode mechanical support (adhesion) and possibly even affect their non-linguistic understanding of support mechanisms (e.g., tape). In sum, by systematically delineating the semantic space of support in the earliest stages of language acquisition, the current findings suggest how core knowledge, in combination with linguistic input, can support spatial language acquisition.

Over the course of the project, various methods were utilized to test the questions of interest, including the Intermodal Preferential Looking coupled with infant eye-tracking, and corpus analysis methods. Further, we developed a new elicited production and forced choice comprehension task specifically adapted for young children (2.5-4.5 years of age). Using this method, we were able to successful test whether children between 20 months and 4 years of age talk about SFB and mechanical support differently (i.e., preferentially mapping SFB to BE on ("the cup is on the table") and mechanical support to lexical verbs ("the picture is hanging on the wall").


The findings from this project have been disseminated in peer-reviewed journals, several professional conferences, and invited research talks at universities. Further, the findings have been disseminated to the community through annual newsletters and local community events. The findings have implications for theories in developmental cognitive psychology and linguistics. They support theories positing that infants possess 'core knowledge' and that this knowledge supports language acquisition. They also support linguistic theories positing that input plays a role in semantic development, and suggests how it may do so.


The findings from this project also have implications for society more broadly by clarifying how two sources of information (core knowledge in combination with linguistic input) can influence spatial language development, specifically in the domain of support. The physical nature of one object supporting another is fundamental to reasoning about the spatial world. The current project extends earlier research suggesting that infants reason about support from below and infants categorize support from below; our findings suggest that such ?core? representations of SFP are privileged in mapping to spatial language. This greater understanding of spatial cognition and spatial language development can be applied to understanding both typical and atypical cognitive and language development.


The activities performed under this project significantly impacted students, including undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups. Students were mentored on all aspects of the research projects, including reading empirical and theoretical papers, subject recruitment, research design, hypothesis testing, data analysis and interpretation, and dissemination of the findings. Students were mentored by two PIs and four students from Montclair State University were supported by this award to work directly with the PI at The Johns Hopkins University. Similarly, one JHU student worked directly with the PI at MSU as a paid research assistant. Thus, students were immersed in highly collaborative research settings.  Students working directly under this award presented at Montclair State University's student research symposium and at both national and international conferences. Three students also earned co-authorship on peer-reviewed manuscripts. Lastly, several undergraduates pursued further graduate training in psychology, including doctoral degrees in developmental cognitive psychology.
